name: Lower
description:
Overview: A floaty wilderness multiday with an nice whitewater canyon at the end.

Flows: There is no gauge on the Coal River, but you can get a general idea of flows from nearby gauges (Liard, Hyland, Nahanni). Flows generally rise high off snowpack melt into May and June, before gradually dropping through the rest of the summer. An early July trip (LIARD RIVER AT LOWER CROSSING @ 4000cms) was a fun medium high flow for kayaking. The guidebook Paddling in Yukon also describes this as a great August or September trip, including for decked canoes (LIARD RIVER AT LOWER CROSSING median flow 1100-1700cms). The actual flow in the Lower Coal reach will only be an estimated ~5-10% of these values. Daily Discharge Graph for LIARD RIVER AT LOWER CROSSING (10BE001).
permits: The two harder drops can be portaged with some effort. Portaging all the rapids would be impractical.

name: Slesse Creek
difficultyClass: Class III with a short IV- canyon
description: Overview: Low volume, gravel bed, many boulder gardens with a short narrow canyon section (“Keyhole Canyon”).
permits: Scout Keyhole Canyon on the drive to the put in

name: Upper
description: Overview: A full day adventure through a series of canyons
permits: Mostly scoutable and portageable with some work, except for the lead in to the crux rapid.

name: Lower Run
difficultyClass: Class II to III (III+ at high water)
description: Overview: Big waves, some holes and boulders, a canyon, and flat water at the end. Large Volume

name: Cameron River
description: Overview: Excellent river-running with small canyons and bedrock rapids.
season: After rain.  Short snowmelt season in the spring.
permits: Moderate - a few rapids would be difficult to walk.

name: Bottom Mile
description: Overview: The last hurrah of the Ashlu.  Steep boulder piles that equate to difficult but good kayaking.
season: No definite window - whenever water spills over the dam.
permits: Easy to moderate, at river level.

name: Kitsumkalum (Kalum) River
difficultyClass: Class III+ to IV.  Pushy at high water - a swim would be unpleasant.
description: Overview: Big water play run.  At high water, one of the best play runs in BC.
season: All year.  May-June for high water snowmelt and best Dog Dish levels.  Fall rain provides frequent high water.
permits: Both of the significant rapids can be scouted and portaged with difficulty.
estimatedTime: 30 min - 2 hr.  Level dependent.  Are you stopping to surf?

name: Skookumchuck Creek
description:
Overview: 16 km of high quality whitewater. River running at medium-high water with more of a creeky feel at medium-low water.

Flows: : There is a painted rock gauge at the takeout. 1 is low, 3 is high. It can certainly be run higher, but does turn very fast and continuous with few eddies and shoreline trees become a real hazard. Typically this river runs at good flows in early to mid summer, after the spring flood.
permits: Scouting is not difficult, however it would take far too long to scout all of the rapids on the run from the bank.

name: Rutherford Creek
difficultyClass: Continuous class IV-V, class V at higher levels.
description: Overview: Continuous boulder rapids studded with some classic bedrock drops.
season: Whistler high water season - quite a bit of water needs to go over the dam to give good flows.
permits: Easy to moderate.

name: Canyon
description: Overview: A short but fun medium volume run on the dry side of the Coast Mountains.
season: July-August in a normal year.  Earlier for high water runs.
permits: Easy scouting, moderate portaging.

name: Duti River
difficultyClass: Class IV+, depending on the level
description: Overview: The Duti offers challenging whitewater in a spectacular remote wilderness setting.
season: August / September. The first descent crew went in July at higher water. The first 2 days were full-on continuous class IV at this level and the lower canyons were very serious. Later in the year (August / Sept) the upper sections are a bit bonier but the main canyon becomes more manageable.
permits: Everything can be portaged with varying levels of difficulty.
estimatedTime: 3 days on the Duti and another 3-6 days on the Skeena depending on your choice of takeout.

name: Little Qualicum Falls
description: Overview: An exciting double drop draped in mystical Vancouver Island rainforest.
season: Rain fed in the fall/winter, snowmelt in the spring.
permits: Easy - scout from the trail network.
estimatedTime: Park and huck; scouting + 2 minutes of paddling.

name: Lower
description: Overview: A glacial read and run blitz underneath one of Canada's most unstable volcanoes.
season: Summer (June-Sept). Can probably scrape down at other times of year.
permits: The whole run can be scouted from the hike in.
estimatedTime: 2 hour hike in, 30 minute paddle out

name: Middle Memekay River
description: Overview: Nice long intermediate canyon run from a small creek down into a river.
season: During and just after rainfall October-May.
permits: The only class IV rapid can be scouted and portaged. Some of the other canyons are mandatory and wood-prone.

name: Similkameen Canyon
description: Overview: Beautiful Deep Canyon running through some unique scenery
permits: Mostly easy

name: Nahatlach River – Francis Lake to Apocynum Campground
description: Overview: Medium volume, continuous boulder gardens, big holes, lots of fun.
permits: Check out Rosegarden and Meatgrinder on the drive to the put-in.

name: Link River
description:
Overview: The shortest river on Vancouver Island

Flows: The Link River (upper Marble River on some maps) flows out of the large Victoria Lake, and is likely runnable consistently from October through May with the exception of very dry spells. Level is judged visually at the Southeast Main FSR bridge or at the campsite. If it looks like enough water to kayak, the canyon below the slides will be good to go. MARBLE RIVER AT OUTLET OF VICTORIA LAKE (08HE002). Limited historical gauge data from 1925-1931; 1932; 1933-1941; 1946-1953. Anything over 10cms should be boatable?

Shuttle: To get to the take out, take the north island highway past Port McNeill, turn west on Highway 30 (The Frigon Road) towards Port Alice. After passing Marble River Provincial Park, but before reaching Port Alice, turn left onto the Southeast Main and follow this ~6km to the Link River Campground. The lower put in is reached by taking the West Main (river left) to a bridge over the tiny Jeune Creek. Either drag boats 200m down this creek to the Link River, or bushwhack 100m directly to the confluence. If you must run the slides, the upper put in is reached by taking Victoria Lake Main (river right), and turning right onto a small branch road that leads to the lake outlet.

On the Water: The best way to explore the river is to bushwhack directly to the confluence of Jeune Creek and the Link River from river left. This puts you at the base of the slides, and at the start of the 1km section of class III down to the campsite on Alice Lake. At the lower put in, you can explore around to scout the big slide. If you decide to run it, just use the upper put in on Victoria Lake for your second lap.
putIn: is reached by taking the West Main (river left) to a bridge over the tiny Jeune Creek
season: October through May except for dry spells.
permits: Boat scoutable below the slides
estimatedTime: 2-3 hours to explore the whole run. 15 minute laps on the lower half.

name: Seymour River – Upper Run
description: Overview: Pool-drop, some flat sections, gravel bed, low volume
permits: Scouting is easy, no portages required

name: Upper
description:
Overview: A fun and scenic class III+ stretch on the Upper Mamquam. The last two kilometres known as the Middle Mamquam is class IV, but please see the dam warning.

Flows: The Mamquam gauge is newly online so we have yet to establish a solid correlation. 45-55cms translates to a nice low or medium-low level (though note that this still has a big volume feel for the last two kilometres). The gauge is quite far downstream (near town), so the correlation may not be consistent.
season: Early summer or after rainfall. The last 2km can be run year-round.
permits: More or less roadside

name: Quesnel River
difficultyClass: Class III+ to IV- (IV at High water)
description: Overview: Big Volume, with play waves at the top. Home of the Unlikely Fest.
permits: Crux can be scouted easily

name: Fraser River – Alexandra Bridge to Yale
description: Overview: Huge volume, pool drop, big crashing waves and swirly eddies, lots of floating. The road is high above the river and accessible only in a few spots.
season: When everything else is too low. Winter and before the snow melt in spring (January to March) and occasionally in fall after a long drought.
permits: Scout Saddle Rock rapid. It takes some exploring to see it from the road. Portage is possible over big boulders (but not very pleasant).
